body:
I think, your Vagrantfile's path contains multibyte character.
Please try moving Vagrantfile to not contains multibyte character directory.

Hi @cmourouvin 

I am sorry you are having issues. Could you please share your complete Vagrantfile as well as the output of Vagrant in [debug mode](http://docs.vagrantup.com/v2/other/debugging.html)? Thanks!

Hi,

There are a lot of issues with Vagrant and encodings. we'd like to fix these but don't actually know how at the moment. We're tracking these in an old meta-issue so I'm closing all these dups. Please search and I'm sure you'll find it. Thanks!

issue.title: Encoding Issues Mega Issue

milestone.title: Secondary
milestone.description: Secondary issues to pull from for point releases. Main composition is non-critical bug reports and requests.

repository.name: vagrant
repository.description: Vagrant is a tool for building and distributing development environments.

issue.body:
I'm creating this issue to just collect and keep track of all encoding issues. I'd rather have one big issue than a bunch of small ones. I'll link to them from here.
- [x] #5595
- [x] #5475 
- [x] #5605
- [x] #5832 
- [x] #5855
- [x] #6056
- [x] #6065
- [x] #6130
- [x] #6571 
- [x] #7106

body: @mitchellh this one seems like it contains enough information to me to reproduce. Do you think it requires any further triage?

@cmourouvin could you provide the values of

```
p Encoding.default_external
p Encoding.default_internal
```

?
@cmourouvin @mitchellh I've got a failing test for this here: https://github.com/samphippen/vagrant/commit/790fa9f8e2ffe927820a3585095f4e9a47f57391

issue.title: samphippen/bugfix/5605

repository.name: vagrant
repository.description: Vagrant is a tool for building and distributing development environments.

issue.body:
Here we implement a naive solution to #5605 which catches the case that
a provided source contains an object which cannot be inspected, because
an object contained within in has an #inspect string that returns a
string that is incompatible with the encoding in
`Encoding.default_external` or a string which cannot be downcast to
7-bit ascii.

The Ruby VM implementation of "#inspect" implements this checking on
these lines of code: http://git.io/vZYNS. A Ruby level override of
this method does not cause this problem. For example:

``` ruby
class Foo
  def inspect
    "😍".encode("UTF-16LE")
  end
```

will not cause the problem, because that's a Ruby implementation and the
VM's checks don't occur.

However, if we have an Object which **does** use the VM implementation
of inspect, that contains an object that has an inspect string which
returns non-ascii, we encounter the bug. For example:

``` ruby
class Bar
  def inspect
    "😍".encode("UTF-16LE")
  end
end

class Foo
  def initialize
     @bar = Bar.new
  end
end

Foo.new.inspect
```

Will cause the issue.

The solution this patch provides basically catches the encoding error
and inserts a string which attempts to help the user work out which
object was provided without blowing up. Most likely, this was caused
by a user having a weird encoding coming out of one of the sources
passed in, but without a full repro case, it's not clear whether a patch
should be applied to a different object in the system.

Closes #5605.
